where $\exp(\mathbf{\Omega} t)$ represents the matrix exponential of $\mathbf{\Omega}$. The transient properties of
$\vec{I}(t)$ can otherwise be straightforwardly obtained by substituting Eq. (\ref{ty5}) into Eq. (\ref{ty3}).

 In fact, the transient characteristics of SMC described by Eq. (\ref{ty5}) can be easily demonstrated by eigenvalues $\omega_i$ and eigenfunction $\vec{\theta}_i$ in frequency domain analysis.
Without loss of generality,  the solution of Eq. (\ref{ty5}) can be expressed by linear combinations of $\exp(\omega_i t)\vec{\theta}_i\equiv\exp(\omega_{i,r} t+i \omega_{i,c} t)\vec{\theta}_{i}$. The positive (negative) real part $\omega_{i,r}$ of the eigenvalues denotes the growing (decaying) time by $1/\omega_{i,r}$ for the $i_{th}$ eigenmode, and the imaginary part $\omega_{i,c}$ denotes its period of oscillation by $2\pi/\omega_{i,c}$. The amplitude of the $j_{th}$ component of eigenfunction $|\theta_{i,j}|$ indicates the weighting of $\nu_j$ in the eigenmode, and the phase angle $(\vartheta_{i,j})$ indicates its lag phase regarding oscillations. Since $\mathbf{\Omega}$ is a non-symmetric matrix, its eigenfunctions are not mutually orthogonal.

\subsection{Eigensystem formulation for multiple SMCs}

We further consider multiple $m$ SMCs mutually coupled via gap junctions.
For this case, Eq. (\ref{ty4}) is straightforwardly extended to be:

where $\exp(\mathbf{\Omega} t)$ represents the matrix exponential of $\mathbf{\Omega}$. The transient properties of
$\vec{I}(t)$ can otherwise be straightforwardly obtained by substituting Eq. (\ref{ty5}) into Eq. (\ref{ty3}).

 In fact, the transient characteristics of SMC described by Eq. (\ref{ty5}) can be easily demonstrated by eigenvalues $\omega_i$ and eigenfunction $\vec{\theta}_i$ in frequency domain analysis.
Without loss of generality,  the solution of Eq. (\ref{ty5}) can be expressed by linear combinations of $\exp(\omega_i t)\vec{\theta}_i\equiv\exp(\omega_{i,r} t+i \omega_{i,c} t)\vec{\theta}_{i}$. The positive (negative) real part $\omega_{i,r}$ of the eigenvalues denotes the growing (decaying) time by $1/\omega_{i,r}$ for the $i_{th}$ eigenmode, and the imaginary part $\omega_{i,c}$ denotes its period of oscillation by $2\pi/\omega_{i,c}$. The amplitude of the $j_{th}$ component of eigenfunction $|\theta_{i,j}|$ indicates the weighting of $\nu_j$ in the eigenmode, and the phase angle $(\vartheta_{i,j})$ indicates its lag phase regarding oscillations. Since $\mathbf{\Omega}$ is a non-symmetric matrix, its eigenfunctions are not mutually orthogonal.

\subsection{Eigensystem formulation for multiple SMCs}

We further consider multiple $m$ SMCs mutually coupled via gap junctions.
For this case, Eq. (\ref{ty4}) is straightforwardly extended to be:
